012package org.postgresql.pljava.example.polyglot;
013
014import java.nio.ByteBuffer;
015import java.nio.CharBuffer;
016import java.nio.charset.CharacterCodingException;
017import static java.nio.charset.StandardCharsets.US_ASCII;
018
019import java.sql.SQLException;
020import java.sql.SQLSyntaxErrorException;
021
022import java.util.Base64;
023import java.util.BitSet;
024import java.util.Objects;
025import static java.util.Optional.ofNullable;
026
027import static java.util.stream.Collectors.toList;
028
029import org.postgresql.pljava.PLJavaBasedLanguage.InlineBlocks;
030import org.postgresql.pljava.PLJavaBasedLanguage.Routines;
031import org.postgresql.pljava.PLJavaBasedLanguage.Routine;
032import org.postgresql.pljava.PLJavaBasedLanguage.Template;
033
034import org.postgresql.pljava.annotation.SQLAction;
035
036import org.postgresql.pljava.model.Attribute;
037import org.postgresql.pljava.model.ProceduralLanguage;
038import org.postgresql.pljava.model.ProceduralLanguage.PLJavaBased;
039import org.postgresql.pljava.model.RegProcedure;
040import org.postgresql.pljava.model.RegProcedure.Call;
041import org.postgresql.pljava.model.RegProcedure.Lookup;
042import org.postgresql.pljava.model.TupleDescriptor;
043import org.postgresql.pljava.model.TupleTableSlot;
044
045/**
046 * Example of a procedural language implemented atop PL/Java.
047 *<p>
048 * Glot64 has a couple of features rarely found in a PostgreSQL PL. First, you
049 * can't use it to do anything, other than print some text to standard output.
050 * That's the server's standard output, which you probably won't even see unless
051 * running the server with standard output to your terminal, as you might run a
052 * test instance under PL/Java's test harness. On a production server, what is
053 * written to standard output may well go nowhere at all, and then it may truly
054 * be said your Glot64 routines do nothing at all.
055 *<p>
056 * Second, Glot64 has the rare property that the compiled form of its code is
057 * easier to read than the source. That's because when you
058 * {@code CREATE FUNCTION} or {@code CREATE PROCEDURE} in Glot64, you write
059 * the {@code AS} part in Base64. It gets 'compiled' by decoding it to ASCII.
060 * (Unless it is malformed Base64 or doesn't decode to ASCII. Then your routine
061 * gets rejected by the validator. Better luck next time.) Then, when you call
062 * the function or procedure, the 'compiled' code is written to standard output.
063 * Therefore,
064 *<pre><code>
065 * CREATE FUNCTION hello() RETURNS void
066 *   LANGUAGE glot64
067 *   AS 'SGVsbG8sIHdvcmxkIQo=';
068 *</code></pre>
069 * defines a function that writes "Hello, world!" when you call it.
070 *<p>
071 * However, Glot64 writes several other things to standard output ahead of the
072 * output of the routine itself. That is the real purpose: to illustrate how
073 * PL/Java's language handler API is arranged, and how the information about the
074 * parameters and result type (or types) will be presented to your code.
075 *<p>
076 * You can declare a Glot64 function or procedure with any number and types of
077 * parameters and return type (or {@code OUT} parameters). Because your routine
078 * will not use any of the arguments or produce any result, it doesn't care how
079 * they are declared. By declaring Glot64 functions in several different ways,
080 * you can see, in the output messages, how the API presents that information.
081 */
082@SQLAction(requires = "pljavahandler language", install = {
083"CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION javatest.glot64_validator(oid)" +
084" RETURNS void" +
085" LANGUAGE pljavahandler AS 'org.postgresql.pljava.example.polyglot.Glot64'",
086
087"COMMENT ON FUNCTION javatest.glot64_validator(oid) IS " +
088"'Validator function for the glot64 procedural language'",
089
090"CREATE LANGUAGE glot64" +
091" HANDLER sqlj.pljavaDispatchRoutine" +
092" INLINE  sqlj.pljavaDispatchInline" +
093" VALIDATOR javatest.glot64_validator",
094
095"COMMENT ON LANGUAGE glot64 IS " +
096"'The glot64 procedural language, which is implemented atop PL/Java, " +
097"and supports functions, procedures, and inline code blocks'",
098
099"CREATE FUNCTION javatest.hello() RETURNS void" +
100" LANGUAGE glot64 AS 'SGVsbG8sIHdvcmxkIQo='",
101
102"CREATE FUNCTION javatest.hello(anyelement) RETURNS anyelement" +
103" LANGUAGE glot64 AS 'SGVsbG8sIHdvcmxkIQo='",
104
105"CREATE FUNCTION javatest.hello(a int4, b int4, OUT c int2, OUT d int2)" +
106" LANGUAGE glot64 AS 'SGVsbG8sIHdvcmxkIQo='",
107
108"CREATE FUNCTION javatest.hello(text, VARIADIC \"any\") RETURNS text[]" +
109" LANGUAGE glot64 AS 'SGVsbG8sIHdvcmxkIQo='",
110
111"CREATE PROCEDURE javatest.say_hello()" +
112" LANGUAGE glot64 AS 'SGVsbG8sIHdvcmxkIQo='",
113
114"DO LANGUAGE glot64 'SGVsbG8sIHdvcmxkIQo='",
115
116"SELECT javatest.hello()",
117
118"SELECT javatest.hello()",
119
120"SELECT javatest.hello(42)",
121
122"SELECT javatest.hello(n) FROM generate_series(1,3) AS t(n)",
123
124"CALL javatest.say_hello()"
125}, remove = {
126"DROP PROCEDURE javatest.say_hello()",
127"DROP FUNCTION javatest.hello(text,VARIADIC \"any\")",
128"DROP FUNCTION javatest.hello(int4,int4)",
129"DROP FUNCTION javatest.hello(anyelement)",
130"DROP FUNCTION javatest.hello()",
131"DO LANGUAGE glot64 'QnllIGJ5ZSEK'",
132"DROP LANGUAGE glot64",
133"DROP FUNCTION javatest.glot64_validator(oid)"
134})
135public class Glot64 implements InlineBlocks, Routines
136{
137    private final ProceduralLanguage pl;
138
139    /**
140     * There must be a public constructor with a {@code ProceduralLanguage}
141     * parameter.
142     *<p>
143     * The parameter can be ignored, or used to determine the name, oid,
144     * accessibility, or other details of the declared PostgreSQL language
145     * your handler class has been instantiated for.
146     */
147    public Glot64(ProceduralLanguage pl)
148    {
149        this.pl = pl;
150    }
151
152    /**
153     * The sole method needed to implement inline code blocks.
154     *<p>
155     * This one merely writes the 'compiled' source text to standard output.
156     * @param inlineSource the source text to be executed as the inline code
157     * block.
158     * @param atomic true if top-level transaction control must be disallowed
159     * within the block. PL/Java will already handle propagating this value to
160     * underlying PostgreSQL SPI calls your code might make, but it is also
161     * available here in case your language has compilation choices it can make
162     * based on that information.
163     */
164    @Override
165    public void execute(String inlineSource, boolean atomic) throws SQLException
166    {
167        System.out.printf("%s inline code block (atomic: %s):\n", pl, atomic)
168            .print(compile(inlineSource));
169    }
170
171    /**
172     * This and {@link #additionalChecks additionalChecks} are the two methods
173     * involved in implementing a validator for the language.
174     *<p>
175     * Each method should simply return normally if its checks pass, or throw
176     * an (ideally informative) exception if not. The work is split into two
177     * methods (which need not both be supplied) because PostgreSQL does not
178     * guarantee that the validator fully ran at the time of creating any
179     * routine. Therefore, while PL/Java will normally call both methods during
180     * validation when a function or procedure is being created, it also will
181     * call {@link #essentialChecks essentialChecks} at runtime, in advance of
182     * calling {@link #prepare prepare}, so this is the place to put checks that
183     * are necessary to support assumptions {@code prepare} relies on.
184     *<p>
185     * For Glot64, this method does nothing. The only check needed at validation
186     * time is whether the source text successfully 'compiles', and the
187     * {@code prepare} method will have to compile the code anyway, so including
188     * that check here would be redundant. It can be included in
189     * {@code additionalChecks}, so a user has useful feedback at create time.
190     * @param subject the proposed Glot64 routine to be validated
191     * @param checkBody whether to perform all checks. When false, depending on
192     * details of the language being implemented, some checks may need to be
193     * skipped. PostgreSQL can call validators with {@code checkBody} false at
194     * odd times, such as during {@code pg_restore} or {@code pg_upgrade}, when
195     * not everything in the database may be as the full suite of checks would
196     * expect.
197     */
198    @Override
199    public void essentialChecks(
200        RegProcedure<PLJavaBased> subject, boolean checkBody)
201    throws SQLException
202    {
203        System.out.printf("%s essentialChecks: checkBody %s\n",
204            subject, checkBody);
205    }
206
207    /**
208     * This and {@link #essentialChecks essentialChecks} are the two methods
209     * involved in implementing a validator for the language.
210     *<p>
211     * Each method should simply return normally if its checks pass, or throw
212     * an (ideally informative) exception if not. See
213     * {@link #essentialChecks essentialChecks} for more on why there are two
214     * methods.
215     *<p>
216     * For Glot64, this is the only method that really checks anything, namely,
217     * that the source text can be 'compiled'. That is work the {@code prepare}
218     * method must do when it is called anyway, so there is nothing to gain by
219     * having it redundantly done in {@code essentialChecks}. Doing it here at
220     * {@code CREATE} time, though, gives helpful feedback to a user.
221     * @param subject the proposed Glot64 routine to be validated
222     * @param checkBody whether to perform all checks. When false, depending on
223     * details of the language being implemented, some checks may need to be
224     * skipped. PostgreSQL can call validators with {@code checkBody} false at
225     * odd times, such as during {@code pg_restore} or {@code pg_upgrade}, when
226     * not everything in the database may be as the full suite of checks would
227     * expect.
228     */
229    @Override
230    public void additionalChecks(
231        RegProcedure<PLJavaBased> subject, boolean checkBody)
232    throws SQLException
233    {
234        System.out.printf("%s additionalChecks: checkBody %s: ",
235            subject, checkBody);
236
237        /*
238         * For Glot64, 'compiling' is purely a matter of string transformation
239         * and has no interaction with database state, so the judgment call can
240         * be made (as here) to include this check even when checkBody is false.
241         */
242        compile(subject.src());
243
244        System.out.printf("ok\n");
245    }
246
247    /**
248     * Prepares an executable template for a routine (a function or procedure).
249     *<p>
250     * The parameter to this method is a {@link RegProcedure}, carrying a
251     * {@link PLJavaBased PLJavaBased} memo. The {@code RegProcedure} exposes
252     * the PostgreSQL catalog information for the routine, and the memo provides
253     * some more information computed and cached by PL/Java. However, at this
254     * stage, no information from any specific call site is presented.
255     *<p>
256     * For example, the memo describes the number, names,  and types of the
257     * routine's inputs (all of its declared parameters that have mode
258     * {@code IN}, {@code INOUT}, or {@code VARIADIC}) and outputs (the ones
259     * with mode {@code INOUT}, {@code OUT}, or {@code TABLE}), each set
260     * presented in the simple form of a {@link TupleDescriptor}.
261     *<p>
262     * Because this information is based only on the routine's declaration,
263     * these tuple descriptors are called {@code inputsTemplate} and
264     * {@code outputsTemplate}. They may contain entries with polymorphic types
265     * that will be resolved to concrete types at a given call site (and
266     * possibly to different concrete types at a different call site). The
267     * {@link BitSet BitSet}s {@code unresolvedInputs} and
268     * {@code unresolvedOutputs} indicate which positions must be resolved
269     * later. If the bit sets are empty, the template {@code TupleDescriptor}s
270     * are already complete descriptors of the inputs and outputs that will be
271     * seen at call sites.
272     *<p>
273     * This method should precompute whatever it can based on the routine's
274     * catalog declaration and the template tuple descriptors only, and return
275     * a {@link Template} instance, which must depend only on this information,
276     * as it will be cached with the {@code RegProcedure} itself, independently
277     * of any call site.
278     *<p>
279     * At a call site, the {@code Template} instance's {@code specialize} method
280     * will be called on a {@link Lookup Lookup} object (conventionally called
281     * {@code flinfo}) representing the call site. At that stage, more specific
282     * information is available, such as fully-resolved {@code TupleDescriptor}s
283     * for the inputs and outputs, and which argument expressions at that call
284     * site have stable values that will not vary in succesive calls made at
285     * that site. The {@code specialize} method should use that information to
286     * generate and return a {@link Routine Routine}, a fully-resolved object
287     * with a {@code call} method ready to be cached at that call site and used
288     * for (possibly many) calls made there.
289     *<p>
290     * When the routine has no polymorphic inputs or outputs, as reported by
291     * empty {@code unresolvedInputs} and {@code unresolvedOutputs} bit sets
292     * at the {@code prepare} stage, a final {@code Routine} can be generated
293     * at that stage, and the {@code Template} returned by {@code prepare} can
294     * simply return it unconditionally (unless it wants to look at which
295     * input expressions can be treated as stable).
296     *<p>
297     * For each call at a given call site, a {@link Call Call} instance will be
298     * passed (conventionally as {@code fcinfo}) to the generated
299     * {@code Routine}'s {@code call} method. The {@code Call} object bears the
300     * actual {@link TupleTableSlot}s from which the routine will fetch its
301     * arguments and to which it will (XXX when implemented) store its
302     * result(s).
303     */
304    @Override
305    public Template prepare(RegProcedure<PLJavaBased> target)
306    throws SQLException
307    {
308        PLJavaBased memo = target.memo();
309
310        BitSet unresolvedIn  = memo.unresolvedInputs();
311        BitSet unresolvedOut = memo.unresolvedOutputs();
312
313        System.out.printf(
314            "%s prepare():\n" +
315            "inputsTemplate   : %s\n" +
316            "unresolvedInputs : %s\n" +
317            "outputsTemplate  : %s\n" +
318            "unresolvedOutputs: %s\n",
319
320            target,
321
322            memo.inputsTemplate()
323                .stream().map(Attribute::type).collect(toList()),
324
325            unresolvedIn,
326
327            /*
328             * Unlike inputsTemplate, outputsTemplate can return null. That can
329             * happen for two reasons: (1) the routine is declared VOID and no
330             * outputs are needed, or (2) it is declared RECORD and will rely on
331             * an output column definition list at every call site, so there is
332             * no outputsTemplate to examine in advance.
333             */
334            ofNullable(memo.outputsTemplate())
335                .map(t ->
336                    t.stream()
337                    .map(Attribute::type)
338                    .map(Object::toString)
339                    .collect(toList())
340                    .toString())
341                .orElse("null"),
342
343            /*
344             * It's also possible for unresolvedOutputs to be null, in the
345             * declared-RECORD-so-nothing-is-known-yet case. (In the VOID case,
346             * it will just be an empty BitSet, meaning no outputs need to be
347             * resolved, just as an empty BitSet would mean any other time. That
348             * makes it simple to test for canSkipResolution, as shown below.)
349             */
350            Objects.toString(unresolvedOut)
351        );
352
353        boolean canSkipResolution =
354            unresolvedIn.isEmpty()
355                &&  null != unresolvedOut  &&  unresolvedOut.isEmpty();
356
357        /*
358         * For this 'language', all compilation can be done early; it does not
359         * need to see resolved type descriptors from flinfo at a call site.
360         */
361        String compiled = compile(target.src());
362
363        /*
364         * This will be the Template object, cached with the RegProcedure.
365         */
366        return flinfo ->
367        {
368            /*
369             * It might be interesting to know which arguments are 'stable' at
370             * this 'flinfo' call site, meaning they will have the same values
371             * in any number of upcoming calls at this site. In a realistic
372             * case, there might be certain arguments we'd be interested in
373             * precomputing values from, and we can use a BitSet to indicate
374             * which arguments we'd like to know the stability of, and the set
375             * returned from inputsStable will show the subset of those
376             * positions where stable expressions have been passed. For this
377             * example, we'll start by setting all bits [0,nargs) and thus ask
378             * about all the arguments.
379             */
380            TupleDescriptor inDescriptor = flinfo.inputsDescriptor();
381            int nargs = inDescriptor.size();
382            BitSet maybeStable = new BitSet(nargs);
383            maybeStable.set(0, nargs);
384
385            System.out.printf(
386                "%s Template.specialize():\n" +
387                "inputsDescriptor : %s\n" +
388                "inputsAreSpread  : %s\n" +
389                "stableInputs     : %s\n" +
390                "outputsDescriptor: %s\n",
391
392                target,
393
394                inDescriptor.stream().map(Attribute::type).collect(toList()),
395
396                flinfo.inputsAreSpread(),
397
398                flinfo.stableInputs(maybeStable),
399
400                /*
401                 * Above, outputsTemplate could return null for two reasons.
402                 * The second reason no longer applies; if the routine is
403                 * declared RECORD and this call site has no column definition
404                 * list, outputsDescriptor throws an exception. But a null
405                 * return is still possible in the VOID case.
406                 *
407                 * Why not an empty descriptor for VOID? An empty descriptor
408                 * really occurs if a function returns t where t is a
409                 * zero-column composite type. Odd thing to do, but allowed.
410                 */
411                ofNullable(flinfo.outputsDescriptor())
412                    .map(d ->
413                        d.stream()
414                        .map(Attribute::type)
415                        .map(Object::toString)
416                        .collect(toList())
417                        .toString())
418                    .orElse("null")
419            );
420
421            /*
422             * This will be the Routine object, cached with the call site.
423             */
424            return fcinfo ->
425            {
426                Call.Context cx = fcinfo.context();
427
428                String subifc = ofNullable(cx)
429                    .map(c -> c.getClass().getInterfaces()[0].getSimpleName())
430                    .orElse("null");
431
432                String maybeAtomic =
433                    (cx instanceof Call.Context.CallContext)
434                    ? String.format("atomic: %s\n",
435                        ((Call.Context.CallContext)cx).atomic())
436                    : "";
437
438                System.out.printf(
439                    "%s Routine.call():\n" +
440                    "collation: %s\n" +
441                    "context: %s\n%s" +
442                    "result:\n%s",
443                    target,
444                    fcinfo.collation(),
445                    subifc, maybeAtomic,
446                    compiled // here we 'execute' the 'compiled' routine :)
447                );
448            };
449        };
450    }
451
452    /**
453     * This method handles 'compiling' Glot64 source code (which is Base64)
454     * into its 'compiled' form, which is ASCII and easier to read than the
455     * source.
456     *<p>
457     * It is factored out here so it can also be conveniently used at validation
458     * time.
459     *<p>
460     * The longwinded style with explicit {@code newEncoder}/{@code newDecoder}
461     * calls is used to get strict checking (instead of lax character
462     * substitution) from the encoder/decoder, to give the most, shall we say,
463     * thorough feedback to the user.
464     */
465    public static String compile(String sourceText) throws SQLException
466    {
467        try
468        {
469            CharBuffer cb = CharBuffer.wrap(sourceText);
470            ByteBuffer bb = US_ASCII.newEncoder().encode(cb);
471            bb = Base64.getDecoder().decode(bb);
472            cb = US_ASCII.newDecoder().decode(bb);
473            return cb.toString();
474        }
475        catch ( CharacterCodingException | IllegalArgumentException e )
476        {
477            throw new SQLSyntaxErrorException(
478                "compiling glot64 code: " + e, "42601", e);
479        }
480    }
481}
